abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Third Water Supply
            and Sewerage Project for Nepal was unsatisfactory due to the
            inexperience of the Borrower (Water Supply and Sewerage
            Board) and unrealistic expectations of the Bank. The Water
            Supply and Sewerage Board lacked the financial income and
            operational management skills to oversee the project. The
            Bank put too much pressure on the Water Supply and Sewerage
            Board to improve its financial performance and meet its loan
            agreements. This situation neglected the main objectives of
            the project and caused several problems. Start-up was slow
            and effectiveness was delayed. The implementation of the
            project was also delayed due to design changes, slowness of
            local civil contractors, concern over sewerage designs, and
            inertia in the Water Supply and Sewerage Board itself. There
            are many lessons to be learned from this situation. First,
            the Bank spent too much time and effort on financial issues
            and illusive objects. It would have been more productive to
            focus on improving source and distribution system management
            and developing the Water Supply and Sewerage Board's
            awareness of its role in the urban sector in Nepal. Second,
            institutional development problems are not always internal.
            It is necessary to review and address the external operating
            environment and the extent to which the government monitors
            or influences institutional performance. Finally, water and
            sewerage projects in urban areas should not be developed in isolation.
